column71: Javier isn't a very good advisor. Also, I appreciate the classes that have homework word problems simulating the real world since it shows the applications of what I am studying.

It's not entirely related, but I wish we would take a more mathematically rigorous approach to at least the 160 series. I think that perhaps making MATH 10B a prerequisite (or a co-requisite with 160A) would be a good idea, and would result in students having less trouble with the material. Double integration isn't covered in 10A, so I think a reason why students tend to struggle with 160B in particular is that they aren't comfortable enough with it due to having had to teach themselves how to do it for 160A (although I got an A in 160B, I can still say from experience that - at least for me - this was the case). Though it's literally the first topic of 10B, and the only thing that's needed for the 160 series from that class, I think it's a good idea to demand even that little bit more mathematical maturity.
I have no graduate advisor yet.
